awd_abstract_narration:
Mammals, including rats and humans, naturally explore novel items and situations. Exploratory behavior, however, is not optimal in all settings. For example, a hungry animal may avoid exploring a novel item when navigating toward a food source or being pursued by a predator. The perirhinal cortex, part of the medial temporal lobe memory system, is known to be important for identifying novelty. However, how do we know when it is appropriate or safe to explore a novel item or situation? Substantial evidence indicates that such cognitive control relies on the prefrontal cortex. Cells in the prefrontal as well as the perirhinal cortex respond to novelty by changing their activity levels.  The mechanisms by which these two, distant brain regions interact in novelty-guided exploration are unknown. Recent work suggests that brain regions communicate by large, low-frequency oscillations, and results from the investigator's laboratory suggest that the particular frequency of oscillation in the perirhinal cortex transmits specific abstract information about the novelty and familiarity of individual items. The present research program addresses the overarching hypothesis that this signaling mechanism between brain regions is used in perirhinal-prefrontal interactions during novelty-guided behavior in rats. The work will impact memory research, neuroscience, and the community at large in several ways. First, the studies promise to delineate the neural mechanisms and brain circuitry underlying recognition memory and novelty-guided behavior. Second, the studies advance our understanding of the role of the prefrontal cortex and of prefrontal-perirhinal interactions in novelty-guided exploration. Finally, the studies hold the promise of revealing a new category of temporal coding in which the frequency of the oscillation enhances the transmission of specific abstract information across brain regions.  In addition, the project provides opportunity for students from Historically Black Colleges and Universities to engage in intensive summer research training, and for local middle and high school students to learn about neuroscience research.

This research project includes a series of experiments that combine electrophysiology, optogenetics, transgenic animals, and behavior to elucidate the mechanisms and circuits by which synchronous neuronal activity guides appropriate exploration of novelty and familiarity. The experiments test the hypothesis that perirhinal-prefrontal interactions are necessary for novelty-guided exploration and modulated by synchronous neuronal activity in specific frequency bands. In vivo experiments employ multiple measures of rhythmic, synchronous activity to understand the temporal codes relaying information within and between the brain regions as a function of behavior, e.g., changes in local field potential (LFP) power in a given region at particular frequencies, changes in LFP coherence between any given pair of regions at particular frequencies, and phase-locking of cells in one region to the LFP in the same region or in other regions. Complimentary in vitro experiments employ state-of the-art optogenetic tools to interrogate the cellular mechanisms that underlie synchronous activity, focusing in particular on the differential roles of interneurons and pyramidal cells. The results from this work advances our understanding of the underlying circuitry of novelty-guided behavior and cognition, as well as of how brain oscillations modulate cognitive processes.

por.por_cntn:
Recognition memory is the capability to discern whether a stimulus has been encountered before or, alternatively, is completely novel. Rats, monkeys, and humans all have a propensity to explore novel items. Such exploratory behavior, however, is not optimal in all settings. For example, a hungry animal may decide not to explore a novel item when navigating toward a food source. The decision whether or not to explore novelty requires recognition memory (including the identification of novelty), identification of the context, and cognitive control. This project further explored the circuitry that underlies all these aspects of recognition memory.  

The perirhinal cortex (PER) has a well-established role in the identification and recognition of individual items and objects. In recognition memory tasks, animals and humans with perirhinal damage are unable to distinguish familiar objects or images in from novel ones. Moreover, PER neurons respond to both the novelty and familiarity of presented objects with a change in firing rate. In earlier NSF-funded work, the Principal Investigator (PI) published evidence that firing rates, alone, do not explain PER involvement in identifying novel and familiar objects. Rather, PER neurons appear to signal novelty and familiarity by firing synchronously at specific frequencies (Ho et al., 2015). During exploration of novel and familiar images, optogenetic stimulation of perirhinal neurons at 30 Hz caused animals to treat a familiar image as if it were novel by exploring it more (Ho et al., Burwell, 2015). This work provided evidence for a new type of temporal code in which a specific frequency of synchronous activity appeared to signal a particular types of information content as opposed to a brain state.

This project allowed further examination of the circuitry that supports novelty exploration. Substantial evidence indicates that the sort of cognitive control required to decide whether or not to explore novel stimuli relies on prefrontal cortex (PFC). Medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) is known to be involved in processing information about novelty. Secondary motor cortex (MOs) in the rodent prefrontal cortex plays an important role in processing sensory information in order to guide appropriate goal-directed behavior. MOs and mPFC have strong anatomical connections to the PER. We employed optogenetic techniques to address the hypotheses that PER-PFC interaction is necessary for novelty guided exploration and that these interactions are modulated by synchronous neuronal activity in the low gamma (30-40 Hz) frequency domain (Ioannou, et al, in preparation). During a spontaneous object recognition (SOR) task, MOs or IL neurons were optogenetically stimulated at 30 Hz. Stimulation at 30 Hz, but not other frequencies, caused rats to treat familiar images as if they were novel by exploring them more. Thus, like the peririhinal cortex, 30 Hz frequency of stimulation in prefrontal cortex yielded resulted in animals treating familiar images as if they were novel.   

Context also plays a role in making the decision whether or not to explore. The PER and the adjacent postrhinal cortex (POR) are both involved in the representation of context. This project also addressed the hypothesis that PER-POR interaction is necessary for context guided behavior ((V. R. Heimer-McGinn, Poeta, Aghi, Udawatta, & Burwell, 2017). In three experiments, we addressed the hypothesis that the POR relies on object and pattern information from the PER to encode representations of context. We found that disconnection of the PER and POR disrupted context-guided spontaneous novel object exploration, but not the association of fear with a context. Our results suggest that contextual fear conditioning may represent a special case of context-guided behavior.  

Finally, we addressed the hypothesis that the POR is also involved in representing non-spatial contexts using electrophysiological methods in behaving rats (Victoria R. Heimer-McGinn, Trettel, Kent, Singh, & Burwell, 2022).  Rats were trained on a task in which the pattern on the floor (nonspatial context) signaled which of two objects was correct regardless of the location of the objects. We showed that POR neurons do indeed signal the onset of nonspatial contexts. 

This project, together with earlier, related NSF-funded work, has transformed how we think about corticohippocampal interactions in recognition memory as well as episodic memory. Among other findings, this project provided 1) evidence that the perirhinal, postrhinal, and medial prefrontal cortices work together when animals are faced with a decision whether or not to explore novelty, 2) evidence for a new type of temporal code in which specific frequencies of synchronous activity signal particular types of information, and 3) evidence that contextual fear conditioning may represent a special case of context-guided behavior that can be subserved by the hippocampus and does not require participation of higher order cortical regions.
